aws::graph::propositions: # Helicopter Lower Hydraulic System Functional Test Details
The yaw servo isolation valve is mounted on the main transmission deck.
The yaw servo isolation valve is activated when the yaw servo isolation switch on the collective stick is in the "off" position.
When the yaw servo isolation switch is in the "off" position, it electrically powers a solenoid that closes the valve.
The yaw servo isolation valve is open when there is no electrical power applied to the valve.
The yaw servo isolation valve is open when the switch on the collective stick is in the "on" position.
An open yaw servo isolation valve allows hydraulic fluid to flow to the tail rotor servo.
An open yaw servo isolation valve allows hydraulic fluid to flow to the yaw load compensator.
During the functional test, the yaw servo isolate switch remained in the "off" position.
During the functional test, electrical power was applied to the helicopter.
Movement of the yaw servo isolation valve was confirmed by physical touch during the test.
The magnetization of the solenoid was confirmed by touching a steel tool to the valve.
A hydraulic mule was installed into the lower hydraulic circuit.
The hydraulic mule provided about 30 bars of hydraulic pressure.
The hydraulic mule was installed via a fitting downstream of the hydraulic pump.
The "HYD" light on the caution-warning panel illuminated during the test.
The "SERVO" light on the caution-warning panel illuminated during the test.
The "LIMIT" light on the caution-warning panel illuminated during the test.
The illumination of these lights was expected due to the upper hydraulic circuit remaining unpowered.
The cyclic stick was manipulated by hand during the test.
The collective stick was manipulated by hand during the test.
The cyclic and collective sticks had forces consistent with hydraulic assistance.
The pedals were manipulated by foot during the test.
Increased resistance occurred with the pedals consistent with forces expected without hydraulic assistance.
The yaw servo isolation switch was placed in the "on" position during the test.
After placing the yaw servo isolation switch in the "on" position, the pedals were manipulated by foot.
The pedals moved with forces consistent with normal hydraulic assistance when the switch was in the "on" position.
The helicopter start up hydraulic checks were performed to functionally test the lower hydraulic circuit.
The start up hydraulic checks are required by Section 4 of the AS350 B3 flight manual.
The checks included a test of the yaw servo isolation valve by switching the yaw servo isolation switch to "off".
The checks included a test of the yaw load compensator accumulator by depressing the "ACCU TEST" button.
The checks were performed with no anomalous results.
The hydraulic mule was powered off after the checks.
The right pedal moved forward due to residual pressure from the yaw load compensator after powering off the hydraulic mule.
The forward movement of the right pedal is normally expected during shutdown of the helicopter.
The hydraulic mule was powered on again to assess the position of the pedals.
The pedal position assessment was performed to evaluate the pilot's stated shutdown procedure after the incident.

text:
# Lower Hydraulic System Functional Test

The yaw servo isolation valve, mounted on the main transmission deck, is activated when the yaw servo isolation switch on the collective stick is in the "off" position, which electrically powers a solenoid that closes the valve. The valve is open when there is no electrical power applied to the valve (when the switch on the collective stick is in the "on" position), allowing hydraulic fluid to flow to the tail rotor servo and yaw load compensator.

During the functional test, the yaw servo isolate switch remained in the "off" position and electrical power was applied to the helicopter. Movement of the yaw servo isolation valve was confirmed by physical touch. Additionally, the magnetization of the solenoid was confirmed by touching a steel tool to the valve.

A hydraulic mule, which provided about 30 bars of hydraulic pressure, was installed into the lower hydraulic circuit via a fitting downstream of the hydraulic pump. The "HYD", "SERVO", and "LIMIT" lights on the caution-warning panel (CWP) illuminated, as would be expected due to the upper hydraulic circuit remaining unpowered. The cyclic and collective sticks were manipulated by hand with the expected forces consistent with hydraulic assistance. The pedals were manipulated by foot. Increased resistance occurred consistent with forces expected without hydraulic assistance. The yaw servo isolation switch was then placed in the "on" position and the pedals were manipulated by foot. The pedals moved with the expected forces consistent with normal hydraulic assistance.

The helicopter start up hydraulic checks, required by Section 4 of the AS350 B3 flight manual, were performed in order to functionally test the lower hydraulic circuit. The checks included a test of the yaw servo isolation valve by switching the yaw servo isolation switch to "off"; and a test of the yaw load compensator accumulator by depressing the "ACCU TEST" button. The checks were performed with no anomalous results. The hydraulic mule was subsequently powered off and the right pedal moved forward due to residual pressure from the yaw load compensator, a result that is normally expected during shutdown of the helicopter.

The hydraulic mule was powered on again in order to assess the position of the pedals when performing the pilot's stated shutdown procedure after the incident.
